questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is diagnosed with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the PKD1 gene. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely involved in the formation of renal cysts in this patient?

choices.text: Dysfunction of polycystin proteins on the primary cilium
Overactivation of chloride and aquaporin channels
Decreased proliferation of renal epithelial cells and increased fluid secretion

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dysfunction of polycystin proteins on the primary cilium

Explanation:

Mutations in PKD1 (polycystin-1) or PKD2 (polycystin-2) lead to the dysfunction of these proteins on the primary cilium, which disrupts calcium signalling and promotes cyst formation.

 

ADPKD- Introduction and aetiology
  • Formation of epithelial-lined cysts in kidneys affecting ~5% of tubules. Despite the small number, cyst growth disrupts surrounding tissue, leading to loss of kidney function.
  • It is autosomal dominant with full penetrance but variable expressivity.
  • Bilaterally enlarged kidneys with cortical and medullary cysts are seen
  • Key defects: (Option D ruled out)
    • Increased cell proliferation and fluid secretion
    • Decreased cell differentiation
    • Abnormal extracellular matrix

Genetic Heterogeneity
  • PKD1 mutations: ~85% of cases.
  • PKD2 mutations: ~15% (milder clinical presentation).
  • Other genes: GANAB and DNAJB11 (rare cases, affecting polycystin-1 trafficking).

Genetics
  • Caused by mutations in PKD1 (polycystin-1) and PKD2 (polycystin-2).
    • PKD1: large G-protein coupled receptor.
    • PKD2: calcium channel protein.
  • Polycystin proteins interact on the primary cilium. (Option C)
    • Dysfunction leads to impaired calcium signalling and cyst formation.

Molecular Mechanisms
  • Polycystin-1 and -2 Complex: Forms a receptor-channel complex involved in calcium signalling and G-protein regulation.
  • Affects processes like cell cycle, cytoskeleton organization, and cell migration.
  • Disruption leads to abnormal calcium signalling, and increased cAMP, promoting cyst growth via chloride and aquaporin channels. (Option A and C ruled out)

Cyst Formation
  • "Second hit" mutation in normal PKD1/ PKD2 allele leads to cyst formation.
  • Partial loss of function initiates cyst growth, accelerated by renal injury or genetic/epigenetic changes.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest presentation of Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hypertension

 

Explanation:

Hypertension is the earliest and most universal symptom of Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)

 

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) clinical presentation:

  • Hypertension: Earliest and most universal symptom.
  • Renal Presentation:
    • Remains normal for decades, but GFR declines rapidly once impaired (4–5 mL/min/year loss)
    • Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)
    • Renal Stones: composed of uric acid, calcium oxalate, or both
    • Hematuria, microalbuminuria, proteinuria
    • Gross hematuria may result from cyst haemorrhage or rupture into the collecting system, potentially leading to retroperitoneal bleeding and fever (suggesting cyst infection).
    • Flank Pain: Often due to cyst bleeding, infections, stones, or tumours.
  • Extrarenal Manifestations:
    • Hepatic Cysts
    • Pancreatic Cysts
    • Cardiovascular Abnormalities:
      • Mitral valve prolapse, aortic regurgitation, coronary aneurysms, asymptomatic pericardial effusions, congenital heart defects, aortic stenosis, and atrial fibrillation.
    • Gastrointestinal Abnormalities: Diverticulosis

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be a case of Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD)?

choices.text: 2 cysts in one kidney of a 20-year-old
2 cysts in each kidney of a 36-year-old
4 cysts in each kidney of a 67-year-old
2 cysts in one kidney of a 30-year-old

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 2 cysts in one kidney of a 30-year-old

Explanation:

30-59 years old should have ≥2 cysts in each kidney to be diagnosed with ADPKD

 

Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD):

Modified Ravine Criteria: Ultrasound-based diagnosis of Type 1 ADPKD

  • Ages <30: At least 2 cysts in one or both kidneys (Option A ruled out)
  • Ages 30–59: At least 2 cysts in each kidney (Option B ruled out) (Option A)
  • Age ≥60: At least 3 cysts in each kidney (Option C ruled out)

 

Investigations
  • Renal Ultrasonography.
    • Non-invasive, used for presymptomatic screening and donor evaluation.
    • Limited sensitivity for PKD2 mutation due to late-onset; may miss smaller cysts.
  • CT Scan
    • More sensitive than ultrasound for detecting smaller cysts.
  • T2-MRI (With/Without Contrast)
    • Detects cysts as small as 2–3 mm using gadolinium contrast.
    • Minimal renal toxicity compared to CT contrast agents.
    • Some cysts may remain undetected even with MRI.
  • Genetic Testing
    • Used in ambiguous cases or atypical presentations.
    • Next-generation sequencing reduces costs and improves sensitivity.
    • PKD1 gene testing is complex and expensive due to the presence of pseudogenes.

Management
  • Blood Pressure Control
    • ACE inhibitors or ARBs
 
  • Antibiotic Treatment for Cyst Infections
    • Preferred Antibiotics: Lipid-soluble (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, quinolones, chloramphenicol)
    • Duration: 4–6 weeks
 
  • Kidney Stone Management
    • Hydration
    • Analgesics for pain relief
 
  • Pain management:
  • Analgesics
  • Surgical Cyst Decompression
  • Nerve Block
 
  • Dialysis and Transplantation:
    • Dialysis Options: Peritoneal dialysis or hemodialysis
    • Challenges with Peritoneal Dialysis: Limited intra-abdominal space, increased risk of hernia and back pain
    • Pre-transplant Nephrectomy: May be needed for large kidneys or recurrent infections to accommodate the graft
 
  • Medications to Slow Disease Progression:
    • mTOR Inhibitors: Sirolimus, everolimus
    • V2R Antagonists: Tolvaptan
    • Somatostatin Analogues: Octreotide-LAR
    • Combination Therapy: Enhances efficacy, reduces side effects

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn presents with respiratory distress and low urine output. Prenatal ultrasound had shown enlarged, echogenic kidneys and reduced amniotic fluid levels. The family history reveals that the parents are related, but neither parent has any complaints. Which gene mutation is most likely responsible for this newborn’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) PKHD1

 

Explanation:

The clinical features, ultrasound findings of enlarged echogenic kidneys, and oligohydramnios with a recessive trait point to Autosomal Recessive Polycystic Kidney Disease. Mutations in the PKHD1 gene cause Autosomal Recessive Polycystic Kidney Disease.

 

Autosomal Recessive Polycystic Kidney Disease (ARPKD).

Genetics
  • PKHD1 gene mutation on chromosome 6p21.1–6p12.2
  • Produces fibrocystin/polyductin (FPC)

Clinical Features
  • Pre-neonatal and Neonatal period: Enlarged echogenic kidneys, oligohydramnios, pulmonary hypoplasia
  • Later stages: Systemic hypertension, progressive renal failure, and liver involvement
  • Liver disease: Congenital hepatic fibrosis (CHF) and Caroli disease
  • Portal hypertension with hepatosplenomegaly, variceal bleeding, and cholangitis

Management
  • Neonatal care: Intensive care and blood pressure control
  • Renal management: Dialysis, kidney transplantation
  • Liver complications: May require liver transplantation or portosystemic shunting for Caroli disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not a pathophysiology of Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)?

choices.text: Accumulation of ultra-large von Willebrand factor (VWF) multimers

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Reduced activity of ADAMTS14 enzyme

 

Explanation:

In Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), the enzyme affected is ADAMTS13, not ADAMTS14.

 

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP):

An acute autoimmune disorder characterised by thrombosis and paradoxical thrombocytopenia.

 

Pathophysiology:

  • Enzyme Deficiency:
    • Results from decreased or absent activity of the enzyme ADAMTS13 (a von Willebrand factor-cleaving protease). (vs Option A)
  • Types of TTP:
    • Congenital TTP: Caused by mutations in the ADAMTS13 gene. Typically asymptomatic until a triggering event (e.g., infection, pregnancy) occurs.
    • Acquired TTP: More common and results from autoantibodies (formed on triggers like- antiplatelet drugs, immunosuppressive agents, HIV infection, estrogen-containing birth control, pregnancy) targeting ADAMTS13 (Option D)
  • Mechanism of Thrombosis:
    • Severely deficient ADAMTS13 activity (<10%) leads to the accumulation of ultra-large von Willebrand factor (VWF) multimers (Option B) → platelet aggregation (Option C) → thrombus formation.

questions.text:
A 35 Y/O male presents with fatigue, petechiae, and easy bruising. Over the past week, she has noticed increasing confusion and intermittent headaches. On examination, her blood pressure is normal, and she has no signs of active bleeding. Laboratory findings show the following:


	Haemoglobin: 7.5 g/dL
	Platelet count: 20,000/mm³
	Blood smear: Schistocytes present
	LDH: Elevated
	Haptoglobin: Low
	Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL
	Coagulation studies: Normal PT and aPTT


What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP)

 

Explanation:

This patient has signs of microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia (schistocytes, low haptoglobin, elevated LDH) and thrombocytopenia, both hallmark features of TTP. The presence of neurologic symptoms (confusion, headaches) and renal impairment also point towards TTP.

 

Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP): A type of microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia that classically has been characterised by the pentad:

  • Fever
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Hemolytic anaemia
  • Renal dysfunction
  • Neurologic dysfunction.
  • TTP results from a decrease or absence of the enzyme ADAMTS13 activity.

 

 

HELLP syndrome (Option A): Typically seen in pregnant women with hypertension and liver dysfunction.

 

DIC (Option B): Presents with abnormal coagulation studies (prolonged PT/aPTT), and widespread bleeding. Schistocytes are uncommon.

 

SLE (Option C): Cause hematologic abnormalities but does not usually present with the characteristic microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia seen in TTP.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old female presents with fatigue, fever, and confusion. She also reports easy bruising and occasional nosebleeds. On examination, she has petechiae on her extremities and mild jaundice.

What is the most effective initial treatment in addition to plasma exchange for this condition?

 

Laboratory findings include:

 


	Hemoglobin: 7.0 g/dL
	Platelet count: 12,000/mm³
	Blood smear: Schistocytes present
	LDH: Elevated
	Haptoglobin: Low
	Creatinine: 1.5 mg/dL
	Coagulation profile: Normal PT and aPTT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Prednisolone

Explanation:

The laboratory findings suggest thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

The mainstay of treatment in TTP is plasma exchange (PEX) with high-dose corticosteroid therapy(Prednisolone).

 

Diagnosis:

Laboratory evaluation plays a critically important role in diagnosing TTP because signs and symptoms are variable, and end-organ damage can be delayed.

  • Anaemia and thrombocytopenia, along with an indication of active hemolysis.
  • Presence of schistocytes
  • Increased unconjugated bilirubin
  • Increased reticulocyte count and increased lactate dehydrogenase.

 

PLASMIC SCORE for TTP diagnosis:

The presence of peripheral schistocytes is required to apply to this score.

 

Features

Points

Platelet Count < 30,000/microlitre

1

Reticulocyte count > 2.5%

1

Indirect bilirubin > 2mg/dL

1

MCV < 90fL

1

INR < 1.5

1

Creatinine < 2 mg/dL

1

Undetectable Haptoglobin

1

 

Score > 5 = High probability of TTP

Score < 5 = Low probability of TTP.

 

Treatment

Plasma exchange (PEX) with high-dose corticosteroid therapy.

The mainstay of treatment in TTP

  • Corticosteroids operate by decreasing the activity of the reticuloendothelial system as well as decreasing autoantibody production.
  • Both the ultra-large VWF multimers and the ADAMTS13 autoantibodies are effectively removed from circulation by plasma exchange therapy.
  • The recommended volume of exchange is one estimated plasma volume (usually 40 mL/kg of body weight) with each treatment.
  • The recommended dose for corticosteroids is 1 mg/kg per day of prednisolone.

Rituximab

An anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody was found to help treat TTP refractory to PEX. It targets B-lymphocytes and has a good response rate in refractory and relapsed TTP.

Caplacizumab

It has a high potential for TTP. It is a humanized monoclonal antibody fragment (a bivalent, variable-domain-only fragment) that attacks the A1 section of VWF and prevents platelet adhesion.

Other

Splenectomy, vincristine, cyclosporine and cyclophosphamide.

Rituximab (Option B) is an option for refractory or relapsing TTP but is not typically part of the initial treatment. Vincristine (Option C) and cyclophosphamide (Option D) are immunosuppressive agents used in other hematologic conditions but are not first-line therapies in TTP.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with fatigue, pallor and decreased urine output for the past three days. She reports a recent history of diarrhoea that started and has now resolved. Physical examination reveals pallor, mild jaundice, and petechiae on the lower limbs. Laboratory studies show haemoglobin of 7.8 g/dL, platelet count of 35,000/mm³, elevated serum creatinine of 2.5 mg/dL, and LDH of 950 U/L.A peripheral blood smear reveals schistocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)

 

Explanation:

Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is the most likely diagnosis, given the history of recent diarrhoea (commonly due to Shiga toxin-producing E. coli), acute kidney injury (elevated creatinine), thrombocytopenia, and microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia (schistocytes and elevated LDH).

 

 

Hemolytic uremic syndrome

  • Thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) is characterised by thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia, and acute kidney injury.
  • HUS is most commonly caused by Shiga toxin (typical HUS) or, less commonly, infections or genetic abnormalities activating the alternative complement pathway (atypical HUS).

 

Aetiology Based Classification:

Types

Description

Typical HUS/ D+HUS
  • Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC), called typical HUS, is the most common cause of HUS.
  • Escherichia coli 0157:H7 (E coli 0157:H7) has been linked to typical HUS.
  • Typical HUS comprises 90% to 95% of HUS.
  • Commonly arises from consuming contaminated food or drink and through person-to-person contact.
  • It has low morbidity compared to atypical HUS.

Atypical HUS/

D-HUS
  • The cause of aHUS is the abnormal activation of the alternative complement pathway.
  • The alternative complement pathway is activated with particular emphasis on regulatory Factor H, stabilises C3, and inactivates C3b.

Secondary HUS
  • HUS secondary to underlying conditions or infections, commonly presenting as aHUS with abnormal complement system activation.
  • The most significant component of this category is HUS caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • Caused by Inherited vitamin B12 metabolism disorder, HIV, influenza virus and malignant hypertension.

 

Clinical manifestations:

  • The typical patient is a child younger than 5 with painful diarrhoea and abdominal cramping between 1 and 10 days after exposure to STEC, with fever and vomiting also present.
  • HUS generally begins 5 to 13 days after the start of diarrhoea.
  • HUS symptoms include renal symptoms, such as anuria, oliguria, and fluid overload, and symptoms related to anaemia, such as syncope, fatigue, and pallor.
  • Petechiae and easy bleeding may be notable due to thrombocytopenia.
  • In adult patients, neurological symptoms such as confusion, seizures, and coma are markedly more prevalent than in children.
  • Clinical presentation of aHUS is usually nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue, and pallor, which can progress to signs of acute kidney injury (AKI), such as oliguria, uremia, and fluid overload.

 

Diagnosis:

Complete blood count and blood metabolic panel suggestive of:

  • Elevated LDH, indirect bilirubin, low haptoglobin, elevated Serum Amylase and lipase
  • Elevated plasma haemoglobin is a diagnostic of hemolytic anaemia as schistocytes in peripheral smears.
  • Stool test: To test for Shiga toxin whenever diarrhoea is present.
  • Genetic testing can also be sent to evaluate the genetic causes of HUS.
  • ADAMTS13 level should be sent to rule out TTP.
  • Testing for the presence of S dysenteriae and S pneumonia should also be performed.

 

Differential Diagnosis:

  • HELLP syndrome
  • Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)
  • Systemic vasculitis
  • Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP)

 

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC): (Option B): DIC is associated with abnormalities in coagulation parameters (prolonged PT, PTT).

 

Systemic vasculitis (Option C): Cause renal impairment and systemic symptoms but typically presents with features like purpura, systemic inflammation, or multiorgan involvement.

 

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) (Option D): Usually presents with more neurological symptoms (altered mental status or seizures) and is not typically preceded by diarrhoea.

questions.text: What is the first-line treatment for atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome (aHUS)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Eculizumab

 

Explanation:

Eculizumab is the first-line treatment for atypical HUS.

 

Treatment:

Types

Treatment

Typical HUS
  • Management of typical HUS caused by STEC is generally supportive.
  • Patients are often volume-depleted, and less volume resuscitation has been linked to an increased need for renal replacement therapy.
  • Blood transfusions and platelet transfusions are provided to avoid thrombotic complications.
  • Antimotility agents and antibiotics are avoided in typical HUS caused by STEC, as they correlate with poorer outcomes, likely due to heightened Shiga toxin exposure.
  • If S dysenteriae or S pneumonia is present, early antibiotics are given to improve the outcomes.

Atypical HUS
  • The cornerstones of treatment for aHUS are first-line treatment with eculizumab and second-line with plasma exchange.
  • Eculizumab is a recombinant monoclonal antibody that targets the C5 component of complement activation by preventing its cleavage.
  • Ravulizumab is a new C5 inhibitor that binds to C5 preventing cleavage and it has similar efficacy to eculizumab but with 4 times as long of a half-life.
  • Adverse effects of eculizumab are infection by encapsulated organisms such as S pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae, and all patients should be given appropriate vaccines and monitored.

Secondary HUS
  • Depends on the treatment of the underlying condition.
  • Eculizumab has some efficacy in treating pregnancy-related secondary HUS.

Ravulizumab (Option B): Considered a second option after eculizumab, depending on clinical needs.

 

Cyclophosphamide (Option C): This is an immunosuppressant used for autoimmune and malignant conditions, but it is not indicated for aHUS.

 

Rituximab (Option D): Targets CD20 on B cells and is used in conditions like autoimmune diseases and lymphomas, but it is not a primary treatment for aHUS.

A 40-year-old female came to OP with a fever, weakness of the right side of her body, and bleeding episodes while brushing. Preliminary investigations revealed

S.Creatinine: 2 mg/dL (0.6-1.1 mg/dl)

Platelet count: 20,000 cells/cu.mm (1,50,000-4,00,000 cells/cu.mm)

Bleeding time: 10 mins (2-7 mins)

PT: 15 sec (11.5-13.5 seconds)

aPTT: 38 sec (21-35 seconds)

Peripheral smear revealed the following



{{caption_text}}



 

What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura

 

Explanation:

Middle-aged female with classical pentad of

  • Fever
  • Neurological manifestations: Stroke (weakness over right side)
  • Thrombocytopenia: Platelet count - 20,000 cells/cu.mm
  • Renal injury: AKI/CKD (elevated creatinine)
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia (MAHA): Schistocytes in peripheral smear is suggestive of Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP)

Schistocytes in Peripheral smear

 

 

 

Although clinical symptoms may give a clue, to differentiate between - Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP), Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP), IgA Vasculitis / Henoch Schonlein Purpura (HSP), Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC), coagulation profile is required as all these has a similar clinical presentation.

 

Differential diagnoses:

 

ITP (Option A ruled out)

TTP (Option C)

HSP (Option A ruled out)

DIC (Option A ruled out)

Age
  • Child (5-15 y)
  • Middle-aged females (20-40y)
  • Middle-aged females >> males
  • Children usually in the first decade
  • No specific age predominance

Cause
  • Autoimmune causes
  • Associated with autoimmune diseases - mainly SLE.
  • Infections: HIV, Hep-C, H.pylori
  • Deficiency/autoantibodies to ADAMTS-13
  • ADAMTS-13 is responsible for cleaving vWF.
  • Deficiency of ADAMTS-13 leads to ↑ vWF levels.
  • IgA-mediated Vasculitis - blood vessels are affected, and platelets are spared
  • Sepsis
  • Trauma
  • Malignancy (AML-M3)
  • Obstetric: Abruptio placenta, amniotic fluid embolism

Clinical features
  • Fever + thrombo- cytopenia
  • Self-resolving in children
  • May cause bleeding manifestations in adults
  • Fever + thrombo- cytopenia
  • MAHA
  • Stroke
  • AKI/CKD

questions.text: Primary cilia of the kidney are present in all of the following except
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Intercalated cells of Collecting duct

 

Explanation:

Cilia are absent in the Intercalated cells of the Collecting duct and the Loop of Henle.

Primary cilia of the kidney:

Introduction

Specialized microtubule-based projections from the apical surface of epithelial cells of the kidney.

Functions

Mainly responsible for signal transduction by

  • Chemosensors: measures electrolyte traversing the tubule
  • Mechanosensors: measure the volume of ultrafiltrate passing through the kidney.

Locations

Present in all epithelial cells of the kidney

  • Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) (Option C ruled out)
  • Distal convoluted tubule (DCT) (Option D ruled out)
  • Principal cells of Collecting duct (Option A ruled out)

EXCEPT: Intercalated cells of Collecting duct & Loop of Henle

Disorders

Mutations in ciliary-associated proteins result in diseases together known as Ciliopathies. A few examples in kidneys are,

  • Autosomal Dominant Variety of Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD)
  • Autosomal Recessive Polycystic Kidney Disease (ARPKD)
  • Medullary Sponge Kidney (MSK)
  • Medullary Cystic Kidney Disease (MCKD) / Autosomal Dominant Tubulointerstitial Kidney Disease (ADTKD)

Correct answer: A) Calcium oxalate

 

Explanation:

IVP shows a bouquet of flowers, suggesting a Medullary sponge kidney (MSK).

The most common complication of MSK is Nephrolithiasis - Calcium oxalate stones.

Medullary sponge kidney:

Description
  • Cystic dilatations of terminal portions of collecting duct

Clinical presentation

Childhood: usually asymptomatic or may have episodes of Recurrent UTI

Adult: 50-60 years

  • Nephrolithiasis: Calcium oxalate stone (most common) (Option A)
  • Recurrent hematuria
  • Pyelonephritis: secondary to recurrent UTI
  • Polyuria: defect in collecting duct receptors
  • anaemia: Peritubular cell damage → ↓ Erythropoietin levels

Diagnosis
  • IVP: Bouquet of flowers (or) Paint brush appearance
  • USG: Associated medullary nephrocalcinosis may be seen
  • CT: NCCT/Helical CT - Best Investigation

Management
  • Treatment of complications
  • UTI prophylaxis

questions.text: A male patient was diagnosed with End Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) at the age of 30y. On evaluation, mutation analysis was positive for the UMOD (Uromodulin) gene. Which among the following is the least likely manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Polycythemia

 

Explanation:

  • The condition associated with UMOD gene mutation is Autosomal Dominant Tubulo-interstitial Kidney Disease (ADTKD) - earlier known as Medullary Cystic Kidney Disease (MCKD).
  • Anaemia is associated with ADTKD (NOT polycythemia)

 

ADTKD:

Description
  • Group of inherited renal disorder characterised by Tubulo-interstitial nephropathy and bland urinary sediments.

Genes
  • UMOD (Uromodulin)
  • MUC-1 (Mucin)
  • Other genes: REN (Renin), HNF1β (Hepatocyte nuclear factor)

Inheritance
  • Autosomal dominant pattern

Manifestations/ Complications
  • Polyuria: Tubulointerstitial disorders have a non-oliguric presentation (Option A)
  • anaemia: Peritubular cell damage → ↓ Erythropoietin levels (Option C)
  • CKD/ESRD: Due to progressive renal damage
  • Gout: usual presentation in adults, mainly in ADTKD-UMOD (Option D)
  • Hypovolemia: mainly seen in ADTKD-REN
  • Liver damage: mainly seen in ADTKD-HNF1β

Diagnosis
  • Urine examination: Bland urinary sediments - most specific finding (RBC/WBC/Epithelial casts) (Option B)
  • USG: Shrunken kidneys
  • Histopathology: Tubular atrophy, tubulointerstitial fibrosis

Management
  • Anti-gout drugs: Allopurinol and Febuxostat are mainly useful in ADTKD-UMOD.
  • Replenishment of body fluids & Supportive care
  • Hemodialysis
